EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The BOWIE WATER TREATMENT PLANT (BWTP) is owned and operated by the

CITY OF BOWIE (City).  To comply with the requirements in 40 CFR 68

Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, the CITY OF BOWIE (City)

developed a Risk Management Program (RMProgram) for the BWTP including

Management System, Hazard Assessment, Accidental Release Prevention

Program (ARPP), and Emergency Response Plan.  The RMProgram main goal is to

reduce the employee and public risk of injury, death, or damage from

accidental release of chemicals.



1    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM



The City has the overall responsibility for implementing and

integrating the ARPProgram into their organization.  In accordance

with the Management System, the City Manager is designated as the

RMProgram Director, and the Water Plant Superintendent is the

RMProgram Manager.  Other qualified individuals are assigned

responsibility for implementing each individual requirement set forth

in the Accidental Release Prevention Program and/or Emergency Response

Plan.  The RMProgram participants include the following positions:



A.   RMProgram Director

B.   RMProgram Manager

C.   Hazard Assessment/Offsite Consequence Analysis Update Officer

D.   Safety Information Officer

E.   Hazard Review Update Officer

F.   Operations Manager

G.   Training Supervisor

H.   Maintenance Supervisor

I.   Compliance Audit Officer

J.   Incident Investigation Officer

K.   Emergency Planning and Response Officer

L.   RMPlan Update Officer



Management systems and responsibilities are described in detail in

the Accidental Release Prevention Program, to ensure every participant

playing a role in the RMProgram understands their responsibilities.



2    REGULATED CHEMICALS AND PROCESSES



Regulated toxic chemicals and processes at the BWTP consist of

storage, transfer, and use of chlorine in the chlorination system.



Chlorine gas is stored as pressurized liquid in five (5) side-by-side

containers located indoors.

Maximum liquid chlorine inventory in each

container is 2,000 lbs.  The maximum process quantity is 10,000 lbs.,

ignoring negligible quantities in the piping.



3    HAZARD ASSESSMENT



The Hazard Assessment has been completed for the BWTP.  Offsite

consequence analysis modeling was performed based on the following

principle elements:



A.   Meteorological parameters used for the dispersion modeling analysis

     were the standards recommended by USEPA and incorporated in the 

     RMP*Comp program. 

     

B.   The largest storage vessel is a 1 Ton Container. 



C.   No mitigation measures were considered. 



D.   Distance to the toxic endpoint for all scenarios was modeled using 

     the RMP*Comp program.



F.   Offsite impact was evaluated with LANDVIEW VI.



There has been no process change since the previous report. 





4    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



A comprehensive Accidental Release Prevention Program Manual was developed and implemented.  The main purpose of the manual is to provide operation and maintenance personnel detailed standard procedures to reduce employee and public risk to injury, death, or property damage from accidental chemical releases.  The manual includes the following elements and complies with requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68 Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.



A.   Management

B.   Safety Information

C.   Hazard Review

D.   Operating Procedures

E.   Training

F.   Maintenance

G.   Compliance Audits

H.   Incident Investigation



Procedures for the Accidental Release Prevention Program are implemented and integrated into routine operation and maintenance practices at the BWTP.  Historical, current and future significant efforts focus on the following areas:



A.   Development of a safety information database essential for the

     successful implementation of other procedures, including

     operation, maintenance, training, compliance audits, incident

     investigation, and emergency plannin

g and response.



B.   Implementation of corrective actions recommended during the most

     recent hazard review completed on March 4, 2011.  This effort is

     one of the most important steps for preventing a chemical release

     or minimize its effects on plant personnel or the public.



C.   Regular review and revision of operating procedures to address

     the safely operating procedures for regulated process systems,

     including all eight (8) elements set forth in the regulation. 

     When combined with the operator training program, current

     operating procedures are essential in ensuring safe operation of

     systems and preventing accidental releases.



D.   Regular review and revision of training programs to ensure plant

     personnel working on or near regulated processes are adequately

     trained and understand both inherent process hazards and

     appropriate response actions to accidental chemical releases. 

     Employees who have received adequate classroom and/or on-the-job

     training and are currently qualified to safely operate the

     regulated systems have received certifications  in writing by the

     RMProgram Manager.  A special training session will be provided

     to plant personnel working on or near regulated processes as soon

     as final revisions to operating procedures are completed.



E.   Regular review and revision of the maintenance program to ensure

     that current, accurate, and complete procedures are provided for

     process equipment in regulated processes.  Efforts were and are

     continuously made for the preventative maintenance of equipment

     per manufacturer's recommendations.  Effective maintenance

     procedures are integral to preventing chemical releases that may

     result from mechanical failure of improperly maintained

     equipment.



5    THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



No accidental releases of regulated chemicals from a regulated process at the BWTP

have occurred in the past five years resulting in any death, injury, or property damage on site, or known offsite impacts (i.e., deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or property damages, or environmental damages).



6    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



BWTP personnel do not respond to uncontrolled releases of chemicals from any regulated process at the BWTP.  Plant employees are limited to responding only to incidental releases covered by maintenance procedures.  Appropriate procedures were initially developed will be updated.  Procedures provide instructions on 1) how to determine if a leak is considered an incidental release, and 2) how to notify local emergency responders in the event of an uncontrolled release.  Procedures were developed to meet regulatory requirements, such as emergency notification, evacuation, training, documentation, availability, etc., under 29 CFR 1910.38(a).  Regulated processes at the BWTP are not included in the community emergency response plan developed under 42 U.S.C. 11003.  The local emergency responder is the Emergency Management Office in association with the City of Bowie Fire Department.  Adequate safety information regarding regulated processes has been provided to the Emergency Management Office who has developed and implemented emergency response plans, provided suitable training, and conducted necessary drills in emergency response for regulated chemical releases from regulated processes.  Although it will not be the responsibility of the plant employees to evacuate offsite areas, addresses and telephone numbers of major public receptors inside a one- (1) mile radius are provided in the plan.  BWTP personnel will work closely with the Emergency Management Office and document coordination activities and communications.



7    ON-GOING AND UP-COMING SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS



There are currently no process modifications or facility upgrade projects ongoing or scheduled that would improve the safety of regulated facilities a

t the BWTP.  However,training of presonnel to include refresher classes on the regulated processes are ongoing as well as maintenance activities on the systems. These activities will serve to improve safety at the facility.
